title: A: Thesis/Claim (0-1)
stimulusHtml:
Thesis/Claim: Responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. (1 point)

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

Examples:

“The development of nuclear technology during the twentieth century boosted economic development but also created new risks. Nuclear energy is usually cheap and clean, but it can lead to nuclear waste and accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima. And while the threat of nuclear destruction can sometimes prevent major wars, nuclear proliferation is a real problem.” (responds to the prompt with an evaluative claim that establishes a line of reasoning)

“In the twentieth century, medical advances led to people living longer and having better quality of life.” (responds to the prompt with a minimally acceptable claim that establishes a line of reasoning)

title: B: Contextualization (0-1)
stimulusHtml:
Contextualization: Describes a broader historical context relevant to the prompt. (1 point)

To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.

Example:

“The Second Industrial Revolution resulted in a much wider array of consumer goods, at prices that more and more people could afford” (relates broader events and developments to the topic)

title: C: Evidence (0–2)
stimulusHtml:
Evidence: Provides specific examples of at least two pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt. (1 point)

Example (acceptable):

“The development of new crops through the Green Revolution greatly decreased starvation during the late twentieth century.”(counts toward earning the point because there is a specific historical example relevant to the prompt)

Example (unacceptable):

“During the late twentieth century a whole host of new technologies transformed social structures.”(does not count toward earning the point because there is no specific information beyond what is provided in the introductory statement)

OR

Supports an Argument: Supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence. (2 points)

Evidence used to support an argument might include:

New modes of communication like radio, television, and internet brought people into closer contact.

New medical innovations, like vaccines and antibiotics, increased human life expectancy and increased populations.

New forms of technology, like birth control and broadcast media, changed culture such as youth culture, reproductive relationships, and globalization of culture.

title: D: Analysis and Reasoning (0–2)
stimulusHtml:
Historical Reasoning: Uses historical reasoning (e.g., comparison, causation, continuity and change over time) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt. (1 point)

To earn the first point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument about how advances in science and technology affected society in the period 1900–2001. The reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced, or the evidence may be overly general or lacking specificity.

Examples of using historical reasoning might include:

Explaining how medical and agricultural innovations led to longer human lives and increased populations

Explaining the negative environmental effects of increasing industrial productivity or easier/faster travel and communications

Explaining the effects of scientific and technological change on social norms and categories (for example, changing gender and family norms, changing views of gender and gender roles)

Explaining the effects of scientific and technological change on culture and/or belief systems (e.g. globalization)

OR

Complexity: Demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence. (2 points)

To earn the second point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding of how advances in science and technology affected society in the period 1900–2001.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through sophisticated argumentation that is relevant to the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining multiple themes or perspectives to explore complexity or nuance; OR

· Explaining multiple causes or effects, multiple similarities or differences, or multiple continuities or changes; OR

· Explaining both cause and effect, both similarity and difference, or both continuity and change; OR

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods or geographical areas. These connections should clearly relate to an argument that responds to the prompt.

A response may demonstrate a complex understanding through effective use of evidence relevant to an argument that addresses the prompt. This may be done in a variety of ways, such as:

· Explaining how multiple pieces of evidence (at least four) support a nuanced or complex argument that responds to the prompt; OR

· Using evidence effectively to demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of different perspectives relevant to the prompt.

This demonstration of a complex understanding must be part of the argument and may be demonstrated in any part of the response.

While it is not necessary for this complex understanding to be woven throughout the response, it must be more than merely a phrase or reference.

Demonstrating complex understanding might include:

Explaining the nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple factors or by considering diverse or alternative perspectives or evidence, such as constructing an argument that scientific and technological advances have, on the one hand, helped bridge old economic, social and cultural divides while, on the other hand, opening new divides and creating new antagonisms and inequalities.

Qualifying or modifying the main argument of the essay to demonstrate awareness of historical complexity, such as constructing an argument that explains how, despite its immense social benefits, the Green Revolution has brought some unintended negative consequences, such as overreliance on genetically modified seeds, greater pesticide use, and increased pressure on ecosystems around the world.

Explaining relevant and insightful connections across time and space, such as explaining how the effects of 20th century medical innovations were very different in developing versus developed societies. In developed societies, lifestyle illnesses like diabetes and heart disease are predominate; while in developing countries infectious diseases are still quite prevalent.
